data.text: Contents
Clostridioides difficile toxin with associated disease ..................................................... 7
Introduction

Infections acquired in the healthcare setting are likely to complicate illness, cause anxiety and discomfort, and can lead to death. It has been estimated that 5,000 deaths annually may be directly attributed to healthcare associated infections. The cost of these infections to the NHS is approximately £1 billion each year and around 15% could be prevented by better application of good practice (National Audit 0ffice, 2000). In most instances, the outcome of an infection is governed by the patient's susceptibility.

The young, the elderly, patients with suppressed immunity and those undergoing invasive procedures are particularly at risk. Therefore, not all healthcare associated infections are preventable. Surveillance is required to understand the extent, cost and effects of healthcare associated infection. It is the foundation for good infection control practice and improving patient care.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to ensure that effective active hospital-based surveillance can be carried out.
Definitions

table_items.text: The presence of Meticillin resistance Staphylococcus aureus bacteria in the blood stream.

Surveillance is a comprehensive method of measuring outcomes associated with processes of care, analysis of data and providing information to those who are giving clinical treatment and care. Surveillance also forms part of clinical audit and clinical governance; it assists in reducing the frequency of adverse events such as infection or injury.

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust

The Site Infection Prevention and Control Committee (IPCC's): are responsible for the review of this policy at least every two years, but more frequently if there are changes to Infection Prevention and Control legislation or guidance.

The Chief Executive has overall responsibility for ensuring that the Trust has the necessary management systems in place to enable the effective implementation of this policy and overall responsibility for the health and safety of staff, patients and visitors
The Director for Infection Prevention and Control (DIPC) will have operational responsibly for the effective implementation of this policy

The Infection Prevention and Control Team (IPCT) are responsible for ensuring all staff are made aware of this policy and advising ward staff on control measures, providing them with the necessary advice

All Staff must comply with this policy and act in a responsible manner, liaising with the IPCT in a timely manner if in need of advice or support. All staff have a responsibility to ensure that infection prevention and control is embedded into their everyday practice and applied consistently at all times
The object of surveillance

Surveillance is the on-going, systematic collection, analysis and interpretation of healthcare data and the timely dissemination of results so that appropriate investigative and control measures can be initiated. Surveillance is done so that we know the extent of the problem that exists.
Objectives include:
Monitoring infection incident rates.
Monitoring trends including the detection of outbreaks.
Providing early warning and investigation of infection problems, and subsequent planning and intervention to control.
Prioritising resource allocation.
Examining the impact on interventions.
Gaining information on the overall quality of patient care.

In summary, surveillance provides ways to identify and clarify quality issues, understand their causes and subsequently identify actions to bring about improvements, which is at the forefront of quality governance. The use of standard surveillance methods by hospitals in England to collect information about infection acquired in the healthcare setting provides national data that could be used as a benchmark by hospitals to measure their own performance. The essential characteristic is that the information is used to improve patient outcomes .
Mandatory surveillance
Surgical Site Infection

In 1997 the surgical site infection surveillance was established as part of the Nosocomial Infection National Surveillance Scheme (NINSS), which was developed to enable hospitals in England to collect data on SSI and use the results to review or change practice as necessary. It has now been renamed the Surgical Site Infection Surveillance Service (SSISS). This service supports both the mandatory surveillance of the SSI in orthopaedics and voluntary surveillance in other categories of surgical procedures. This Trust has participated in this scheme since 1997.

Participating hospitals are required to collect data, using standard data collection forms, for three – month surveillance periods, on all patients undergoing surgery in a chosen category. The surveillance is targeted on surgical procedures that are relatively common and / or associated with a relatively high risk of infection, and which are likely to require at least three days of post-operative hospital stay. These are procedures where the maximum benefit from surveillance is likely to be obtained.

Every patient who undergoes a procedure in the chosen category is included in the surveillance, and a small dataset collected about the patient and the operation. Each patient is then followed up prospectively whilst they are in hospital, and following discharge (up to 30 days post operatively).
Bacteraemia

Reporting of Staphylococcus aureus (including Meticillin resistant) bacteraemia is a statutory requirement of the Department of Health (DOH). All S aureus bacteraemia are reported by the Director of Infection Prevention and Control via SGSS, a database of all alert organisms, collected locally and nationally via regional epidemiology centres for local and national comparison, relevant data is also sent electronically within the SGSS system to the local Health Protection Team. There is also a mandatory real time electronic HCAI website for reporting MRSA bacteraemia and Clostridioides difficile infection. The Chief Executive is required by the Department of Health to validate the figures by the 15th of the following month. The data for both these reporting systems is created and maintained by the laboratory staff.
The Trust collects data regarding the results of elective and emergency MRSA screens for MRSA colonisation/acquisition as per DOH requirements. This consists of:
Numbers of new isolates screened for MRSA on admission
Numbers of new isolates screened for clinical reasons
Numbers of new isolates where reason for screening is unknown
Numbers of new isolates in hospital staff
As well as this data, information is sent on the total numbers of MRSA inpatients in the Trust.
The Board Quality Corporate Team receives the information on a monthly basis from a joint report created by the Infection Control team and the Microbiology administrator.
The MRSA bacteraemia rates are reported nationally, all Trusts are ranked and the data is interpreted as a quality performance indicator for Clinical Negligence Schemes for Trusts.
All cases of MRSA bacteraemia and Clostridium difficile are subject to a detailed Route Cause Analysis (RCA).
Clostridioides difficile toxin with associated disease

Clostridioides difficile rates are seen as an indicator of prudent antibiotic use. In line with recommendations of Winning Ways (2003), the DOH has directed all hospital trusts to report laboratory isolates of C difficile GDH and toxin positive in anyone over the age of 65 years in both the hospital setting and in the community. This is also part of the mandatory surveillance required by DOH via the electronic HCAI website; this is validated by the Chief Executive on a monthly basis.
COVID-19 situation reports

COVID -19 SitReps are data collection tool that was established in March 2020, as part of information system through NHS Digital to collect and analyse COVID-19 related data. The collective data collection is broken down across a number of distinctive SitReps that aggregate flows of activity data. The data from SitReps provide the information that is urgently required by the NHS to understand the demands COVID-19 is placing across the health care sector nationally. The information provided through SitReps are collected in a timely and efficient manner and cover different service settings and provider types. Daily SitReps are submitted to NHSE/I through Strategic Data Collection System of NHS Digital. The collection of data for each relevant SitReps will continue until such time as the SitReps are withdrawn.
Glycopeptide resistant enterococci (GRE) and E coli
All bacteraemia associated with GRE and E coli must be reported via the SGSS system.
Serious incidents associated with infection

Winning Ways (2003) established a responsibility for high quality information on healthcare associated infection to be collated as a means to track progress and investigate adverse incidents. Examples of serious adverse incidents include:
Outbreaks of infection which involve transmission within the hospital and cause morbidity among patients and have a significant impact on hospital activity.
Infected healthcare worker/patient which involves a ‘look back' exercise. Mainly involving cases such as COVID-19, Tuberculosis, v CJD and blood borne infections.
Breakdown of infection control procedures with an actual or potential for cross infection. For example, failure to sterilise and hospital acquired Legionella.
These adverse incidents must be reported to the Public Health England, Occupational Health and the CCG who will provide help and support for management and control of the incident.
Laboratory surveillance
Objects of laboratory Surveillance

Reports by microbiologists to the Communicable Disease Surveillance Centre (CDSC) constitute, together with notifications of infectious diseases, are the foundation of communicable disease surveillance in England and Wales. (Health Protection Guidance 2010).
There are 4 objectives of laboratory surveillance:
Detection of changes in disease patterns, including outbreaks, to enable early preventative action to be taken when appropriate.
Evaluation of disease control measures.
Provision of data for health service planning.
Provision of information for opportunities and priorities for research through the creation of disease registers.
What is reported?
All clinically significant infections caused by organisms listed in Appendix 1.
Asymptomatic infections of clinical or epidemiological relevance, i.e. viral infection in pregnancy and asymptomatic persons with human immune virus (HIV).
All significant organisms isolated from blood cultures.
Any organisms causing meningitis, encephalitis or endocarditis.

Organisms for which there is a HPA or other control programme. To unusual infections for which reporting may have educational value and infections for which the severity or rarity may become the focus of public or professional concern.
All gonococci irrespective of site and antibiotic sensitivity.
Any systemic fungal infection, or in the case of Cryptococcus, infection diagnosed using antigen tests.
All cases of hepatitis. Chronic infections are reported when occurring in children, pregnant women and healthcare workers.
All cases of syphilis.

Reports are made to the CDSC as soon as the organism is identified. These reports are sent by SGSS electronic reporting and if applicable via the electronic HCAI website. New HIV diagnoses are reported by the laboratory with epidemiologic input from the HIV/Aids Care team. The laboratory also reports any isolate with antibiotic sensitivity via AmSurv, (which is an electronic reporting system), linked to the pathology computer.
Certain infection reports contain personal health information. These reports are listed below.

INFECTIONS FOR WHICH PATIENT NAMES ARE REQUESTED Brucella  Listeria  Poliomyelitis Diphtheria  Lyme  Rubella Haemophilus influenzae  Measles  Salmonella Hepatitis A   Meningococcus  Streptococcus Gp B Hepatitis B   Mumps  Tetanus
Hydatid  Mycobacterium (africanum,
Bovis, leprae, tuberculosis)
Legionella spp  Pertussis  Vibrio Leprosy  Pneumococcus  VTEC – 0157 Covid-19
Information available to the public

The Trust recognises that patients have a right to know what is happening in their hospital and has therefore fostered a culture of openness. Specific Trust infection data is available to members of the public on request, and other infection data such as MRSA bacteraemia rates and Clostridium Difficile rates are displayed on the Infection Control Notice Boards on the wards
The Infection Prevention and Control Annual Report which contains the year's infection rates printed within it is available to the public on the hospital Web site
Training requirements

All Trust staff to undertake Mandatory Infection Prevention and Control up dates. The IPCT has primary responsibility for providing training on the policy where needed. Managers have the responsibly to support the IPCT by ensuring that staff are able to attend training sessions in response to identified needs.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the IPCC, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local policies and guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Director Harm Free and the Associate Director Harm Free Care of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 1)
